content.text: To embed accreditation preparation into daily school operations through systematic evidence collection, continuous self-evaluation, and strategic alignment with CIS/WASC standards—making accreditation a natural outcome of excellent practice, not a separate compliance burden.
CIS and WASC evaluate school operations, governance, and educational programs through their respective frameworks.
WASC focuses on student learning outcomes and continuous improvement.

content.title: WASC Focus on Learning Criteria
items: Support for Student Personal and Academic Growth

content.text: Pursuing dual accreditation from CIS and WASC enhances operational rigor and learning-focused reflection.

subsections.title: Standards Crosswalk: Mapping Handbook to CIS/WASC

content.text: The crosswalk demonstrates alignment between daily practices and CIS/WASC standards.

subsections.title: Evidence Index: What to Collect and Where to Store It

content.text: The Evidence Index is a centralized catalog of all documentation required for accreditation.
The self-study process involves a structured timeline and methodology to ensure comprehensive evaluation.

content.title: Typical Accreditation Timeline
items: Year 1: Decision to pursue accreditation, initial application, evidence audit.
Year 2: Form Self-Study Steering Committee, evidence gathering, draft self-study.
Year 3: Submit self-study, prepare for visit, receive accreditation decision.

content.text: Engaging stakeholders through surveys and focus groups is critical for gathering feedback.
Preparation for the accreditation visit includes logistics planning and scheduling.

subsections.title: Mini Self-Reviews and Continuous Accreditation Readiness

content.text: Conducting termly mini self-reviews ensures ongoing readiness for accreditation.
Action plans should be integrated into the School Improvement Plan (SIP) to ensure continuous improvement.
A comprehensive checklist of evidence and artifacts is essential for accreditation.
Clear roles and responsibilities for all stakeholders involved in the accreditation process are vital.
